text:
No worries, I'll try my best to respond within reason as well, but sometimes it get's crazy as well :smiley:
And to answer your first question I think drawing is a great complement to 3D animation, and one I love is actively observing your surroundings.
I try and use every spare moment in my day to observe the people around me, the way they walk, the gestures they make, the expressions. Helps bolster the mental reference library I can pull from when Animating
And because animation can be very broad, having separate interests can positively and indirectly affect your animation.

My vimeo is definitely not updated, but feel free to look at all the awful animation I made in the past
<https://vimeo.com/jubapolati>

And I sometimes post any drawings and other animated things on instagram.
<https://www.instagram.com/juba.polati/>

attachments.title: Juba Polati
attachments.text: I'm always looking to improve my craft and become a better artist, it's a challenge that I hope to carry throughout my life, until the end of my days.

attachments.title: Login • Instagram
attachments.text: Welcome back to Instagram. Sign in to check out what your friends, family & interests have been capturing & sharing around the world.

text: Learning 3D from scratch is tough, but once you get through the basics it becomes second nature and you can focus on the art side of it, you seem to be off to a good start though. Have you found something you really enjoy doing? And you're using what program, maya?
